sentences.sentence: The two Moles( 鼹鼠 ) settled that part of the business pretty quickly.
There was some dispute( 争执 ) as to which way up Uncle Andrew ought to be put into the hole,
and he had a very narrow escape from being put in head foremost( 首先 ).
Several animals said his legs must be his branches and therefore the gray, fluffy( 毛茸茸的 ) thing (they meant his head) must be his root.
But then others said that the forked end of him was the muddier and that it spread out more, as roots ought to do.
So finally he was planted right way up.
When they had patted( 拍打 ) down the earth it came up above his knees.
“It looks dreadfully( 极其 ) withered( 枯萎的 ),” said the Donkey( 驴子 ).
“Of course it wants some watering,” said the Elephant.
“I think I might say (meaning no offense( 冒犯 ) to anyone present) that, perhaps, for that sort of work, my kind of nose—”
“I object to that remark very strongly,” said the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ).
But the Elephant walked quietly to the river, filled her trunk with water, and came back to attend( 照料 ) to Uncle Andrew.
The sagacious( 聪慧的 ) animal went on doing this till gallons( 加仑，容量单位 ) of water had been squirted( 喷射 ) over him,
and water was running out of the skirts of his frock-coat( 男礼服大衣 ) as if he had been for a bath with all his clothes on.
In the end it revived( 使...苏醒 ) him. He awoke from his faint( 昏厥 ). What a wakening it was!
But we must leave him to think over his wicked( 邪恶的 ) deed (if he was likely to do anything so sensible( 明智的 )) and turn to more important things.
Strawberry trotted( 小跑 ) on with Digory on his back till the noise of the other animals died away,
and now the little group of Aslan and his chosen councilors was quite close.
Digory knew that he couldn’t possibly break in on so solemn( 庄重的 ) a meeting, but there was no need to do so.
At a word from Aslan, the He-Elephant, the Ravens, and all the rest of them drew aside.
Digory slipped( 滑下 ) off the horse and found himself face to face with Aslan.
And Aslan was bigger and more beautiful and more brightly golden and more terrible than he had thought.
He dared not look into the great eyes.
“Please—Mr. Lion—Aslan—Sir,” said Digory, “could you—may I—please, will you give me some magic fruit of this country to make Mother well?”
He had been desperately hoping that the Lion would say “Yes”; he had been horribly afraid it might say “No.” But he was taken aback when it did neither.
“This is the Boy,” said Aslan, looking, not at Digory, but at his councilors. “This is the Boy who did it.”
“Oh dear,” thought Digory, “what have I done now?”
“Son of Adam,” said the Lion. “There is an evil( 邪恶的 ) Witch( 女巫 ) abroad in my new land of Narnia. Tell these good Beasts how she came here.”
A dozen different things that he might say flashed through Digory’s mind, but he had the sense to say nothing except the exact truth.
“I brought her, Aslan,” he answered in a low voice.
“For what purpose?”
“I wanted to get her out of my own world back into her own. I thought I was taking her back to her own place.”
“How came she to be in your world, Son of Adam?”
“By—by Magic.”
The Lion said nothing and Digory knew that he had not told enough.
“It was my Uncle, Aslan,” he said. “He sent us out of our own world by magic rings, at least I had to go because he sent Polly first,
and then we met the Witch( 女巫 ) in a place called Charn and she just held on to us when—”
“You met the Witch( 女巫 )?” said Aslan in a low voice which had the threat( 威胁 ) of a growl( 咆哮声 ) in it.

“She woke up,” said Digory wretchedly( 难过地 ). And then, turning very white, “I mean, I woke her. Because I wanted to know what would happen if I struck a bell. Polly didn’t want to. It wasn’t her fault. I—I fought her. I know I shouldn’t have. I think I was a bit enchanted( 使迷惑 ) by the writing under the bell.”
“Do you?” asked Aslan; still speaking very low and deep.
“No,” said Digory. “I see now I wasn’t. I was only pretending.”
There was a long pause. And Digory was thinking all the time, “I’ve spoiled( 弄糟 ) everything. There’s no chance of getting anything for Mother now.”
When the Lion spoke again, it was not to Digory.
“You see, friends,” he said, “that before the new, clean world I gave you is seven hours old, a force of evil( 邪恶 ) has already entered it; waked and brought hither( 到这里 ) by this son of Adam.”
The Beasts, even Strawberry, all turned their eyes on Digory till he felt that he wished the ground would swallow him up.
“But do not be cast down( 沮丧 ),” said Aslan, still speaking to the Beasts. “Evil( 邪恶 ) will come of that evil( 恶魔 ),
but it is still a long way off, and I will see to it that the worst falls upon myself.
In the meantime( 同时 ), let us take such order that for many hundred years yet this shall be a merry land in a merry world.
And as Adam’s race has done the harm, Adam’s race shall help to heal( 结束 ) it. Draw near, you other two.”
The last words were spoken to Polly and the Cabby( 马车夫 ) who had now arrived.
Polly, all eyes and mouth, was staring at Aslan and holding the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s hand rather tightly.
The Cabby( 马车夫 ) gave one glance at the Lion, and took off his bowler hat: no one had yet seen him without it.
When it was off, he looked younger and nicer, and more like a countryman and less like a London cabman( 马车夫 ).
“Son,” said Aslan to the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I have known you long. Do you know me?”
“Well, no, sir,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Leastways( 至少 ), not in an ordinary manner of speaking. Yet I feel somehow, if I may make so free, as how we’ve met before.”
“It is well,” said the Lion. “You know better than you think you know, and you shall live to know me better yet. How does this land please you?”
“It’s a fair treat, sir,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ).
“Would you like to live here always?”
“Well you see sir, I’m a married man,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “If my wife was here neither of us would ever want to go back to London, I reckon( 认为 ). We’re both country folks really.”
Aslan threw up his shaggy( 毛发蓬松的 ) head, opened his mouth, and uttered( 说 ) a long, single note; not very loud, but full of power.
Polly’s heart jumped in her body when she heard it.
She felt sure that it was a call, and that anyone who heard that call would want to obey it and (what’s more) would be able to obey it,
however many worlds and ages lay between.
And so, though she was filled with wonder, she was not really astonished( 吃惊的 ) or shocked when all of a sudden a young woman,
with a kind, honest face stepped out of nowhere and stood beside her.
Polly knew at once that it was the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s wife, fetched out of our world not by any tiresome( 折磨人的 ) magic rings,
but quickly, simply and sweetly as a bird flies to its nest.
The young woman had apparently been in the middle of a washing day, for she wore an apron( 围裙 ), her sleeves were rolled up to the elbow( 手肘 ), and there were soapsuds( 肥皂泡沫 ) on her hands.
If she had had time to put on her good clothes (her best hat had imitation( 仿制的 ) cherries( 樱桃 ) on it) she would have looked dreadful( 令人讨厌的 ); as it was, she looked rather nice.
Of course she thought she was dreaming.
That was why she didn’t rush across to her husband and ask him what on earth had happened to them both.
But when she looked at the Lion she didn’t feel quite so sure it was a dream,
yet for some reason she did not appear to be very frightened.
Then she dropped a little half curtsey( 屈膝礼 ), as some country girls still knew how to do in those days.
After that, she went and put her hand in the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s and stood there looking round her a little shyly.

article_info.previous: 胆小的Uncle Andrew 不仅错过了动物开口说话的伟大时刻，又被一群动物追赶，结果吓得昏死了过去。动物们对Uncle Andrew的身份充满了好奇。经过讨论，大多数动物认为他是一棵树。

article_info.share_words: The young woman had apparently been in the middle of a washing day, for she wore an apron, her sleeves were rolled up to the elbow, and there were soapsuds on her hands.

analysis: 文中提到：“But the Elephant walked quietly to the river, filled her trunk with water, and came back to attend to Uncle Andrew… and water was running out of the skirts of his frock-coat as if he had been for a bath with his clothes on.”由此可知，是大象用象鼻给Uncle Andrew浇水，因此选A。

question.en: What did Digory request the Lion to do?

options.en: To give him the magic fruit.
To give him the magic spell.
To give him plenty of money.

analysis: 文中提到：“Could you. . . will you give me some magic fruit of this country to make Mother well?”由此可知，Digory追上Aslan的时候，请求他给自己一些魔法水果去治好自己的母亲，因此选A。

question.cn: 狮子对Digory的请求是什么反应？
question.en: What was the Lion’s response to Digory’s request?

analysis: 文中提到：“But he was taken aback when it did neither.”由此可知，狮子对于Digory的请求，并没表示他是否要答应请求，因此选C。

question.cn: 根据对话，为什么Digory把女巫带到纳尼亚?
question.en: According to their conversation, why did Digory take the Witch into Narnia?

options.cn: 因为他想把女巫带离现实世界。
options.en: Because he wanted to get her out of the real world.

options.cn: 因为他认为女巫会死在现实世界。
options.en: Because he thought the Witch would die in the real world.
Because he wanted to save the Witch.

analysis: 文中提到：“I want to get her out of my own world back into her own. I thought I was taking her back to her own place.”由此得知，Digory仅仅是想把女巫带离自己所处的那个真实的世界，然后回到本属于她的世界，因此选A。

question.cn: 在哪种情况下马车夫愿意永远住在纳尼亚？
question.en: In what condition did the Cabby agree to live in Narnia forever?

options.cn: 他的妻子和他一起留在那儿。
options.en: When his wife lived there with him.

options.cn: 他的孩子和他一起留在那儿。
options.en: When his kids lived there with him.

options.cn: 他的父母和他一起留在那儿。
options.en: When his parents lived there with him.

analysis: 文中到：“If my wife was here neither of us ever want to go back to London, I reckon. We’re both country’s folk, really.”马车夫同意永远住在纳尼亚的条件是他的妻子也留在这儿，因此选A。
